bullet_points.bullet_point_text: The United Nations Office of Internal Oversight Services (OIOS) is the UN system’s primary internal oversight organ, created to strengthen internal accountability across the Organization by undertaking audits, investigations, inspections, monitoring and evaluation, and advisory work to ensure the proper use and protection of UN resources and to promote transparency, accountability and risk awareness across UN entities.

questions.question: A UN field mission needs to reallocate funds rapidly to provide emergency shelter after a natural disaster. Management asks OIOS to ensure the reallocated resources are properly used and risks minimised. Which combination of OIOS modalities would be the most appropriate first-line approach to both assure stewardship and inform immediate corrective measures, while reserving more intrusive steps for substantiated misconduct?
options: Immediately open investigations into alleged misconduct and pursue forensic audits across all staff and contractors before addressing programme performance or offering management advice.
Rely solely on monitoring and evaluation to track outcomes and adjust programming over time, postponing audits or inspections until after the emergency response is complete.

Conduct a performance and compliance audit of the reallocation, deploy targeted inspections to the affected offices, perform ongoing monitoring and evaluation of outputs, and provide advisory recommendations to management—reserving investigations only if evidence of fraud or misconduct emerges.
Request an external audit by Member State auditors to certify the reallocation before any internal actions are taken.

explanations.0: Incorrect. While investigations (bullet point 2) are essential when fraud or corruption is suspected, opening immediate, broad investigations and forensic audits before assessing programme efficiency, compliance and operational causes can be disruptive and may miss management-level fixes that audits, inspections and advisory work can provide (bullet points 1, 3).
explanations.1: Incorrect. Monitoring and evaluation (bullet point 4) are vital for tracking effectiveness and outcomes, but M&E alone does not assess regulatory compliance, financial stewardship or localized operational weaknesses—functions that audits and inspections are designed to address (bullet points 1, 1, 3).
explanations.2: Correct. This option combines OIOS’s audit function (systematic financial, compliance and performance assessments) with targeted inspections to diagnose localized operational weaknesses, M&E to appraise programme outputs/outcomes, and advisory work to guide corrective action. Investigations are appropriately reserved for when evidence indicates fraud or misconduct (bullet points 1, 1, 3, 4, 2).
explanations.3: Incorrect. External audits may provide assurance but are slower and may not have the operational context or mandate to do targeted inspections, M&E or advisory work that OIOS provides internally to promote timely corrective action (bullet point 0).

options: An external auditing body wholly independent of the Secretariat whose only role is to report directly to the General Assembly and has no working relationship with Secretariat management.
An internal Secretariat unit whose sole purpose is to implement executive management decisions and provide routine administrative support to departments.

An oversight office structurally located within the Secretariat but endowed with an independent mandate to examine, report on and advise about resource use and staff conduct, thereby both assisting the Secretary-General and providing accountability to Member States.
A disciplinary tribunal empowered to impose sanctions on staff and to execute management decisions without advisory or evaluative functions.
